item.title: final, const and beyond
item.description:
What are your thoughts on the following piece of code?

public String someGibberishMethod() {
	int length = someMethodReturningLength();
	int sum = 0;

	for (int index = 0; index < length; ++index) {
	   // some code that updates the sum variable
	}

	SomeClass someClass = new SomeClass(sum);
	int sumValueInsideSomeClass = someClass.getSumValue();
	// use someText, maybe log or something

	String someText = someClass.doSomeOperation(/*some parameters*/);
	// use someText, maybe log or something
	return someText;
}

item.title: An Unfair World of Tuples, Anons., var and auto
item.description:
It all began when I wanted to return more than one value from one of the methods. Although my attempts ended futile, it was fun exploring and musing how things could have been.

There are at least a couple of options to return multiple values from a method:-

  1. return an instance of a class that holds the values
  2. return a tuple

item.title: Crazy Brackets – [](){}();
item.description: What does this cryptic bracket sequence mean? What programming language is it?

item.description: The question is, in C++, how do detect if an object is allocated on the stack or heap.

item.title: Typesafe Logger
item.description: Article co-authored with Sanjeev, and published on CodeProject PROBLEM Every application logs a whole bunch of diagnostic messages, primarily for (production) debugging, to the console or the standard error device or to files.

item.title: Thinking Currying
item.description: Currying is a mathematical concept based on lambda calculus. It is a technique of operating on a function (taking multiple arguments) by splitting and capable of chaining into a series of single argument functions.

item.title: Simple Array Class For C++
item.description: This is a simple array like class for C++, which can be used as a safe wrapper for accessing a block of memory pointed by a bare pointer.

item.title: CComPtr Misconception !!!
item.description: This is about a killer bug identified by our chief software engineer in our application.

item.title: Extension Methods – A Polished C++ Feature
item.description: Extension Methods is an excellent feature in C# 3.0. It is a mechanism by which new methods can be exposed from an existing type (interface or class) without directly adding the method to the type.
